TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants , all of whom are NORP citizens , live in GPE . They were born in DATE , DATE , CARDINAL , DATE , DATE and DATE respectively .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE each applicant concluded a contract with ORG ( an insurance company incorporated in GPE ) , according to the terms of which he or she paid an insurance premium in exchange for an annuity pension . The size of the DATE pensions varied CARDINAL NORP lei ( ORG ) and LAW ( between the equivalent of MONEY ( ORG ) and CARDINAL at the time ) .

CARDINAL . NORP On different dates between CARDINAL and DATE ORG stopped paying the pensions , in some cases , or refused to start paying them , in other cases , invoking a change in the interest rate of ORG and calling for the termination of the contracts .

CARDINAL . On unspecified dates in DATE , the applicants brought civil actions against ORG , seeking the payment of the pension arrears to date and requiring the company to abide by the contracts of DATE .

CARDINAL . All the applicants obtained final and enforceable judgments DATE , by which the domestic courts ordered ASITO to pay the pension arrears and to resume the execution of the contracts . The courts found the contracts to be valid and dismissed ORG ’s requests to terminate them or to exempt it from abiding by them on the ground of force majeure , which in ORG ’s view was constituted by the economic crisis , inflation and the change in the interest rate of ORG . The ORG was not presented with information on whether those judgments were complied with by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Prosecutor General lodged an “ appeal in the interest of the law ” with ORG . According to ORG , the appeal had the purpose of clarifying the controversy surrounding the contracts and of setting a uniform practice for all courts .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG issued a judgment deciding the dispute between ORG and the pension beneficiaries in favour of the former . In particular , it ruled that the economic crisis , inflation and the change in the interest rate of ORG could be relied upon by ORG in order unilaterally to avoid the annuity contracts . It also ruled that its judgment was binding on all the courts , although it could not , however , affect already existing judgments and it could not be used against the parties to proceedings which had already been decided .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , on different dates , ASITO brought civil actions against the applicants asking for the termination of the contracts concluded in DATE . It relied on the same arguments as in the first sets of proceedings and also the judgment of ORG of DATE .

CARDINAL . DATE and DATE ASITO obtained final favourable judgments against all the applicants . The courts dismissed the ORG submissions to the effect that the matter of the unilateral denunciation of the contracts by ASITO on grounds of hardship had already been resolved by final judgments and found instead that the subject matter of the proceedings which had ended in final judgments favourable to the applicants had been different , because those proceedings had been concerned with the enforcement of the annuity contracts up to the moment of their termination , while the subject matter of the new proceedings was the termination of the contracts .

CARDINAL . On DATE , after the ORG communicated the present cases to the ORG , ORG upheld a revision request lodged against its judgment of DATE by a group of ASITO pensioners who are not applicants in the present cases . ORG quashed its previous judgment while finding inter alia that ORG could not rely on the economic crisis , inflation and the change in the interest rate of ORG for avoiding its annuity contracts .

“ Grounds for revision
Revision may be requested :
When new and essential facts or circumstances have been discovered , that were unknown and could not have been known earlier ;
